text:
a tiny, but nevertheless hugely useful feature if you ever have to deal with `NamedTuple` in 1.6 is that the constructor is now more reasonable and works over any iterator of appropriately typed pairs
```julia> NamedTuple([:a=>1])
(a = 1,)

julia> NamedTuple(Symbol(string(a))=> a for a ∈ 1:3)
(1 = 1, 2 = 2, 3 = 3)

julia> NamedTuple(Dict(:a=>1))
(a = 1,)```

elements.text: a tiny, but nevertheless hugely useful feature if you ever have to deal with
in 1.6 is that the constructor is now more reasonable and works over any iterator of appropriately typed pairs

julia> NamedTuple([:a=>1])
(a = 1,)

julia> NamedTuple(Symbol(string(a))=> a for a ∈ 1:3)
(1 = 1, 2 = 2, 3 = 3)

julia> NamedTuple(Dict(:a=>1))
(a = 1,)

text: Oh that is glorious. I used to have to do some pretty gnarly things to get things working properly with NamedTuples.

elements.text: Oh that is glorious. I used to have to do some pretty gnarly things to get things working properly with NamedTuples.

text: yeah, it used to get pretty ugly sometimes

elements.text: yeah, it used to get pretty ugly sometimes

text: this feature got added when I made a PR saying that "splatting (;...)` is too slow, we need new constructors, and then Jeff came along and said "oh, let's  just magically fix that splatting is slow".  So now we have the constructors *and* splatting is faster

elements.text: this feature got added when I made a PR saying that "splatting (;...)` is too slow, we need new constructors, and then Jeff came along and said "oh, let's  just magically fix that splatting is slow".  So now we have the constructors

text: I think you can skip `string` in `NamedTuple(Symbol(string(a))=> a for a ∈ 1:3)`, `Symbol` automatically calls `string` on anything that isn't string-y
it's definitely new as of *some* version post 1.0, don't know when

```               _

  | | | | | | |/ _` |  |
  | | |_| | | | (_| |  |  Version 1.0.5 (2019-09-09)
 _/ |\__'_|_|_|\__'_|  |  Official <https://julialang.org/> release
|__/                   |

julia> Symbol(2)
Symbol("2")```
ok, don't know how I didn't know that
